shortname: Consumption of fixed capital of corporations
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2013–2017: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1951–2012: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2017: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Compensation of employees paid by financial corporations sector
simpledes: Compensation of employees paid by financial corporations sector is the total value of income accruing to employees as remuneration for their work paid by the financial corporations sector. The financial corporations sector includes all private and public enterprises that provide financial services to the markets.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Compensation of employees paid by general government
simpledes: Compensation of employees paid by general government is the total value of income accruing to employees as remuneration for their work paid by general government sector (central government, state government, local government, and social security funds).The government sector - in the national accounts - includes are national, regional local governement, social security administrations, and more generally all entities relying primarily upon public financing (taxes, contributions, and other compulsory payments).

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Compensation of employees paid from the rest of the world

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1975–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Foreign direct investment income paid to the rest of the world
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income [total fiscal income ranking]]+[Fiscal capital income [total fiscal income ranking]]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/chancelpiketty2017widworld/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas (2017).Indian Income inequality, 1922-2015: From British Raj to Billionaire Raj?[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: Tax units are individuals (40% of total population). Excludes capital gains.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2013 from: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 1950–2022: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1950–2022: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The government sector - in the national accounts - includes are national, regional local governement, social security administrations, and more generally all entities relying primarily upon public financing (taxes, contributions, and other compulsory payments).

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1980–1998: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.  The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/n-k-bharti-wealth-inequality-class-and-caste-in-india-1961-2012/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Nitin Kumar Bharti (2018), Wealth Inequality, Class and Caste in India; [/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/WorldInequalityLab_WP2024_09_Income-and-Wealth-Inequality-in-India-1922-2023_Final.pdf/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bharti, Nitin Kumar; Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas; Somanchi, Anmol (2024).Income and Wealth Inequality in India, 1922-2023: The Rise of the Billionaire Raj [/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: In 1961 and 1971 data covers rural areas only. Net wealth is reported since 1981. In 1971, net wealth is estimated using the liabilies at the bracket level (assuming individuals remain in the same bracket). In 1961, liabilities are estimated assuming the liability/gross wealth ratios at the bracket level from 1971, and using the 1971 proportions of individuals having any kind of liability. In 2002 and 2012 series are corrected using Forbes lists, and the top of the survey distribution is replaced by a Pareto distribution.

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations. However it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). So we use it as our reference concept (with tax havens correction). To be improved.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

simpledes: National agricultural land is agricultural land owned by the national economy. Agricultural land is defined as land devoted to agriculture measured at their market value. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: National agricultural land is agricultural land owned by the national economy. Agricultural land is defined as land devoted to agriculture measured at their market value. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Book-value national wealth is the sum of value of assets according to the books (balance sheets) on which they are carried. It is the difference between net national wealth and national net corporate wealth. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Book-value national wealth]=[Market-value national wealth ]+[Residual corporate wealth]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Book-value wealth equals aggregate measure for domestic produced assets + land of housing, corporations and government + net foreign assets.

simpledes: Book-value national wealth is the sum of value of assets according to the books (balance sheets) on which they are carried. It is the difference between net national wealth and national net corporate wealth. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Book-value national wealth]=[Market-value national wealth ]+[Residual corporate wealth]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Book-value wealth equals aggregate measure for domestic produced assets + land of housing, corporations and government + net foreign assets.

shortname: National business and other non-financial assets
simpledes: National business and other non-financial assets are agricultural land and other domestic non-financial assets owned by the national economy and measured at their market value.  The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: National business and other non-financial assets
simpledes: National business and other non-financial assets are agricultural land and other domestic non-financial assets owned by the national economy and measured at their market value.  The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: National residual corporate wealth is the total value of debts and legal obligations of the corporate sector (companies), minus the total value of its assets. The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: National residual corporate wealth is the total value of debts and legal obligations of the corporate sector (companies), minus the total value of its assets. The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Net national wealth is the total value of assets (cash, housing, bonds, equities, etc.) owned by the national economy, minus its debts. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Market-value national wealth ]=[National non-financial assets]+[Net foreign assets]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Net national wealth is the total value of assets (cash, housing, bonds, equities, etc.) owned by the national economy, minus its debts. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Market-value national wealth ]=[National non-financial assets]+[Net foreign assets]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2017: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2017: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Property income paid from the rest of the world
simpledes: Property income paid abroad is the total value of payments made by the national economy accruing to property owners as remuneration for using their property.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Property income paid to the rest of the world]=[Foreign direct investment income paid to the rest of the world]+[Portfolio and other income paid to the rest of the world]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2017: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: estimated value (see DINA guidelines). These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2017: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

technicaldes: [Taxes on production and imports, less subsidies]=[Taxes on production and imports]-[Subsidies on production and imports]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2017: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. simpledes: Private agricultural land is agricultural land held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private agricultural land]=[Personal agricultural land]+[Non-profit agricultural land]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Net private wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities of corporations, etc.) held by private owners (households and foundations), minus their debts. In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Net private wealth]=[Private non-financial assets]+[Private financial assets]-[Private debt]

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Private pension funds & life insurance are pension funds and life insurance held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private pension funds & life insurance]=[Personal pension funds & life insurance]+[Non-profit pension funds & life insurance]

The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1980–1998: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Social protection: social assistance in kind
technicaldes: [Social protection: social assistance in kind]=[Social contributions]+[Indirect taxes]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1981–2012: estimated from other components; 1980: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL]1975: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2017: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Post-tax national income is the sum of primary incomes over all sectors (private and public), minus taxes.
technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/government-redistribution-and-development-global-estimates-of-tax-and-transfer-progressivity-1980-2019-wid-world-working-paper-2023-17/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Fisher-Post, Matthew and Gethin, Amory (2023), "Government Redistribution and Development, Global Estimates of Tax-and-Transfer Progressivity, 1980-2019" [/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: 2019-2021 series are estimated by applying the 2018 ratio of pretax to posttax income by generalized percentile.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income [total fiscal income ranking]]+[Fiscal capital income [total fiscal income ranking]]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/chancelpiketty2017widworld/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas (2017).Indian Income inequality, 1922-2015: From British Raj to Billionaire Raj?[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: Tax units are individuals (40% of total population). Excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.  The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/n-k-bharti-wealth-inequality-class-and-caste-in-india-1961-2012/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Nitin Kumar Bharti (2018), Wealth Inequality, Class and Caste in India; [/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/WorldInequalityLab_WP2024_09_Income-and-Wealth-Inequality-in-India-1922-2023_Final.pdf/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bharti, Nitin Kumar; Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas; Somanchi, Anmol (2024).Income and Wealth Inequality in India, 1922-2023: The Rise of the Billionaire Raj [/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: In 1961 and 1971 data covers rural areas only. Net wealth is reported since 1981. In 1971, net wealth is estimated using the liabilies at the bracket level (assuming individuals remain in the same bracket). In 1961, liabilities are estimated assuming the liability/gross wealth ratios at the bracket level from 1971, and using the 1971 proportions of individuals having any kind of liability. In 2002 and 2012 series are corrected using Forbes lists, and the top of the survey distribution is replaced by a Pareto distribution.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.

method: Modeled estimates based on the systematic combination of survey and tax data, national accounts and Environment Input-Output tables. Estimates represent emissions associated with individual investments (i.e. these are emissions associated with “capital formation“, attributed to individual who own firms). This indicator does not include emissions associated with individual consumption and government collective expenditures. While these estimates provide WID.world's best efforts to measure emissions inequality across the world, it should be noted that estimates quality is “low to very low“ given poor data quality and availability on pollution in most countries. It should also be noted that there are different ways to measure carbon footprints, which can lead to different takes on the issue (inequality in emissions is lower when looking at consumption-related emissions only and increases when factoring in investment-related emissions). See sources for more details.

simpledes: Post-tax national income is the sum of primary incomes over all sectors (private and public), minus taxes.
technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.

method: 2019-2021 series are estimated by applying the 2018 ratio of pretax to posttax income by generalized percentile.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income [total fiscal income ranking]]+[Fiscal capital income [total fiscal income ranking]]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.

longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/n-k-bharti-wealth-inequality-class-and-caste-in-india-1961-2012/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Nitin Kumar Bharti (2018), Wealth Inequality, Class and Caste in India; [/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/WorldInequalityLab_WP2024_09_Income-and-Wealth-Inequality-in-India-1922-2023_Final.pdf/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Bharti, Nitin Kumar; Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas; Somanchi, Anmol (2024).Income and Wealth Inequality in India, 1922-2023: The Rise of the Billionaire Raj [/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: In 1961 and 1971 data covers rural areas only. Net wealth is reported since 1981. In 1971, net wealth is estimated using the liabilies at the bracket level (assuming individuals remain in the same bracket). In 1961, liabilities are estimated assuming the liability/gross wealth ratios at the bracket level from 1971, and using the 1971 proportions of individuals having any kind of liability. In 2002 and 2012 series are corrected using Forbes lists, and the top of the survey distribution is replaced by a Pareto distribution.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

method: We cumulate inflation rates from the following sources; 1901-2012: price index provided by the researchers (see source); 2013-2021: GDP deflator from the World Bank; 2022: GDP deflator from the IMF World Economic Outlook.

method: Modeled estimates based on the systematic combination of survey and tax data, national accounts and Environment Input-Output tables. Estimates represent emissions associated with individual investments (i.e. these are emissions associated with “capital formation“, attributed to individual who own firms). This indicator does not include emissions associated with individual consumption and government collective expenditures. While these estimates provide WID.world's best efforts to measure emissions inequality across the world, it should be noted that estimates quality is “low to very low“ given poor data quality and availability on pollution in most countries. It should also be noted that there are different ways to measure carbon footprints, which can lead to different takes on the issue (inequality in emissions is lower when looking at consumption-related emissions only and increases when factoring in investment-related emissions). See sources for more details.

method: Modeled estimates based on the systematic combination of survey and tax data, national accounts and Environment Input-Output tables. Estimates include emissions embedded in imports and exports of goods and services. Estimates represent emissions associated with individual consumption and with government collective expenditures. This indicator does not include emissions associated with individual investments. While these estimates provide WID.world's best efforts to measure emissions inequality across the world, it should be noted that estimates quality is “low to very low“ given poor data quality and availability on pollution in most countries. It should also be noted that there are different ways to measure carbon footprints, which can lead to different takes on the issue (inequality in emissions is lower when looking at consumption-related emissions only and increases when factoring in investment-related emissions). See sources for more details.

longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: Distributional estimates: see [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-carbon-inequality-1990-2019-wid-world-working-paper-2021-22/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel (2021) “Global Carbon Inequality, 1990-2019“ [/URL_TEXT][/URL] and updates; Aggregates: see [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/carbonaggregates/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Burq and Chancel (2021) “Aggregate carbon footprints on WID.world“[/URL_TEXT][/URL]

longtype: Average per capita group emissions for percentile pXpX+1 or PXpY
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: Distributional estimates: see [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/global-carbon-inequality-1990-2019-wid-world-working-paper-2021-22/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel (2021) “Global Carbon Inequality, 1990-2019“ [/URL_TEXT][/URL] and updates; Aggregates: see [URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/carbonaggregates/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Burq and Chancel (2021) “Aggregate carbon footprints on WID.world“[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Modeled estimates based on the systematic combination of survey and tax data, national accounts and Environment Input-Output tables. Estimates include emissions embedded in imports and exports of goods and services. This indicator represents emissions associated with individual consumption and government collective expenditures. This indicator also includes a component representing emissions associated with individuals' investments. While these estimates provide WID.world's best efforts to measure emissions inequality across the world, it should be noted that estimates quality is “low to very low“ given poor data quality and availability on pollution inequality in most countries. It should also be noted that there are different ways to measure carbon footprints, which can lead to different takes on the issue (inequality in emissions is lower when looking at consumption-related emissions only and increases when factoring in investment-related emissions). See sources for more details.

shortname: Consumption of fixed capital of corporations
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2013–2017: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1951–2012: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Compensation of employees paid by financial corporations sector
simpledes: Compensation of employees paid by financial corporations sector is the total value of income accruing to employees as remuneration for their work paid by the financial corporations sector. The financial corporations sector includes all private and public enterprises that provide financial services to the markets.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

shortname: Compensation of employees paid by general government
simpledes: Compensation of employees paid by general government is the total value of income accruing to employees as remuneration for their work paid by general government sector (central government, state government, local government, and social security funds).The government sector - in the national accounts - includes are national, regional local governement, social security administrations, and more generally all entities relying primarily upon public financing (taxes, contributions, and other compulsory payments).

Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. simpledes: The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
technicaldes: [Book value of corporations]=[Corporate non-financial assets ]-[Corporate debt (non-equity liability)]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

shortname: Corporate business and other non-financial assets
simpledes: Corporate business and other non-financial assets are agricultural land and other domestic non-financial assets owned by the corporate sector (companies). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
technicaldes: [Corporate business and other non-financial assets ]=[Corporate agricultural land]+[Corporate other domestic capital]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Corporate debt is debts or legal obligations owned by the corporate sector (companies). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.

simpledes: Corporate equity debt is the total value of equity debts of the corporate sector (companies). longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Corporate financial assets are intangible assets whose value is derived from a contractual claim (bank deposits, bonds, and stocks) owned by the corporate sector (companies). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).

simpledes: Corporate housing assets are places of residence and land they built on owned by the corporate sector (companies). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
technicaldes: [Corporate housing assets ]=[Corporate dwellings ]+[Corporate land underlying dwellings ]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Net corporate wealth is the total value of assets (cash, housing, bonds, equities, etc.) owned by the corporate sector (companies), minus its debts. simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.

source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

(2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
